answer_html: The series \(\sum_{k=1}^\infty b_k = \sum_{k=1}^\infty \frac{1}{k}\) diverges (it’s worth remembering - or being able to show with the integral test - that \(\sum_{k=1}^\infty \frac{1}{k^p}=\sum_{k=1}^\infty \frac{1}{k^p}\) converges if \(p > 1\) and diverges if \(p \leq 1\)).The conclusion is that the series diverges!
answer_latex:
The series $\sum_{k=1}^\infty b_k = \sum_{k=1}^\infty \frac{1}{k}$
diverges (it's worth remembering - or being able to show with the
integral test - that $\sum_{k=1}^\infty \frac{1}{k^p}=\sum_{k=1}^\infty \frac{1}{k^p}$ converges if
$p > 1$ and diverges if $p \leq 1$).The conclusion is that the series diverges!
hints_html: Compare the highest exponents of the numerator and the denominator to make an educated guess. Then confirm your guess using the limit comparison test.
hints_latex:
Compare the highest exponents of the numerator and the denominator to
make an educated guess. Then confirm your guess using the limit
comparison test.
hints_raw: Compare the highest exponents of the numerator and the denominator to make an educated guess. Then confirm your guess using the limit comparison test.
question: 2 (b)
sols_html:
When we look at this series, we note that the leading power of the numerator is k4 and the leading power of the denominator is k5. Thus, for k very large, we would expect the terms in the series to look like k4/k5 = 1/k.

We will use the limit comparison test with

\[\begin{aligned} a_k = \frac{k^4 - 2k^3 + 2}{k^5 + k^2 + k} \text{ and } b_k = \frac{1}{k}\end{aligned}\]

We compute

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{a_k}{b_k} &= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} (\frac{k^4 - 2k^3 + 2}{k^5 + k^2 + k})/(\frac{1}{k}) \\ &= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{k^5 - 2k^4 + 2k}{k^5 + k^2 + k} \\ &= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{k^5/k^5 - 2k^4/k^5 + 2k/k^5}{k^5/k^5 + k^2/k^5 + k/k^5} \\ &= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1 - 2/k + 2/k^4}{1 + 1/k^3 + 1/k^4} \\ &= \frac{1-0+0}{1+0+0} = 1\end{aligned}\]

As this limit is nonzero and finite, \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} a_k\) converges if and only if \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} b_k\) converges.

The series \(\sum_{k=1}^\infty b_k = \sum_{k=1}^\infty \frac{1}{k}\) diverges (it’s worth remembering - or being able to show with the integral test - that \(\sum_{k=1}^\infty \frac{1}{k^p}\) converges if \(p > 1\) and diverges if \(p \leq 1\)).

The conclusion is that the series diverges!
sols_latex:
When we look at this series, we note that the leading power of the
numerator is \emph{k}\textsuperscript{4} and the leading power of the
denominator is \emph{k}\textsuperscript{5}. Thus, for \emph{k} very
large, we would expect the terms in the series to look like
\emph{k}\textsuperscript{4}/\emph{k}\textsuperscript{5} = 1/\emph{k}.

We will use the limit comparison test with

\begin{align*}
a_k = \frac{k^4 - 2k^3 + 2}{k^5 + k^2 + k} \text{ and } b_k = \frac{1}{k}
\end{align*}

We compute

\begin{align*}
\lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{a_k}{b_k} &= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} (\frac{k^4 - 2k^3 + 2}{k^5 + k^2 + k})/(\frac{1}{k}) \\
&= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{k^5 - 2k^4 + 2k}{k^5 + k^2 + k} \\
&= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{k^5/k^5 - 2k^4/k^5 + 2k/k^5}{k^5/k^5 + k^2/k^5 + k/k^5} \\
&= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1 - 2/k + 2/k^4}{1 + 1/k^3 + 1/k^4} \\
&= \frac{1-0+0}{1+0+0} = 1
\end{align*}

As this limit is nonzero and finite, $\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} a_k$ converges
if and only if $\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} b_k$ converges.

The series $\sum_{k=1}^\infty b_k = \sum_{k=1}^\infty \frac{1}{k}$
diverges (it's worth remembering - or being able to show with the
integral test - that $\sum_{k=1}^\infty \frac{1}{k^p}$ converges if
$p > 1$ and diverges if $p \leq 1$).

The conclusion is that the series diverges!
sols_raw:
When we look at this series, we note that the leading power of the numerator is ''k''<sup>4</sup> and the leading power of the denominator is ''k''<sup>5</sup>. Thus, for ''k'' very large, we would expect the terms in the series to look like ''k''<sup>4</sup>/''k''<sup>5</sup> = 1/''k''.

We will use the limit comparison test with
:<math>
a_k = \frac{k^4 - 2k^3 + 2}{k^5 + k^2 + k} \text{ and } b_k = \frac{1}{k}
</math>

We compute
:<math>\begin{align}
\lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{a_k}{b_k} &= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} (\frac{k^4 - 2k^3 + 2}{k^5 + k^2 + k})/(\frac{1}{k}) \\
&= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{k^5 - 2k^4 + 2k}{k^5 + k^2 + k} \\
&= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{k^5/k^5 - 2k^4/k^5 + 2k/k^5}{k^5/k^5 + k^2/k^5 + k/k^5} \\
&= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1 - 2/k + 2/k^4}{1 + 1/k^3 + 1/k^4} \\
&= \frac{1-0+0}{1+0+0} = 1
\end{align}
</math>

As this limit is nonzero and finite, <math>\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} a_k</math> converges if and only if <math>\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} b_k</math> converges.

The series <math>\sum_{k=1}^\infty b_k = \sum_{k=1}^\infty \frac{1}{k}</math> diverges (it's worth remembering - or being able to show with the integral test - that <math>\sum_{k=1}^\infty \frac{1}{k^p}</math> converges if <math>p > 1</math> and diverges if <math>p \leq 1</math>).

The conclusion is that the series diverges!
statement_html:
This problem contains three numerical series. For each of them, find out whether it converges or diverges. You should provide appropriate justification in order to receive credit.

\[\begin{aligned} \sum_{k=1}^\infty \frac{k^4-2k^3+2}{k^5+k^2+k}\end{aligned}\]
statement_raw:
''This problem contains three numerical series. For each of them, ﬁnd out whether it converges or diverges. You should provide appropriate justiﬁcation in order to receive credit.''

:<math>
\sum_{k=1}^\infty \frac{k^4-2k^3+2}{k^5+k^2+k}
</math>
